lead_paragraph: Harold T. Martin III, described by his ex-wife as a hoarder, broke rules by taking home top-secret material, officials said, but they struggled to connect him to leaked documents.

byline.contributor: Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and Matt Apuzzo contributed reporting from Washington, and Jo Becker from New York.
byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and DAVID E. SANGER

headline.print_headline: Hoarder, Yes, but a Leaker? U.S. Isn’t Sure
headline.main: N.S.A. Suspect Is a Hoarder. But a Leaker? Investigators Aren’t Sure.

snippet: Harold T. Martin III, described by his ex-wife as a hoarder, broke rules by taking home top-secret material, officials said, but they struggled to connect him to leaked documents....
abstract: Intelligence and FBI officials continue to investigate why Navy veteran and former National Security Agency contractor Harold T Martin III, arrested in August, had large amounts of highly classified NSA materials in his Maryland home; government analysts had suspected connection between Martin's cache and documents published online, including some through WikiLeaks, that did not come from Edward Snowden, but have not been able to definitively link them to Martin.
